title-group.article-title: Prediction and enhancement of the acoustic performance of a spark ignition engine intake air filter box

abstract.p: The present work has resulted in the development of numerical and experimental methodologies for prediction of the acoustic performance of an air filter box of an internal-combustion engine for automotive applications. With the aim of characterizing its fluid-dynamic behaviour and acoustic attenuation, the latter is first analysed as an isolated component. Typical performance parameters such as the discharge coefficient CD, the pressure losses, the noise reduction and the transmission loss are experimentally and numerically evaluated. Different numerical approaches are considered, including complete three-dimensional computational fluid-dynamics analyses and finite element–boundary element procedures. The latter also take into account the interaction with the vibrating structure. The preliminary air-box design is also modified through the introduction of a column resonator and a Helmholtz resonator. Both the base and the modified system are finally coupled to the whole engine to estimate the gas-dynamic noise emitted by the intake system. The new architectural solutions of the intake system are characterized by improved acoustic performances and also preserve a good power output of the entire engine system. In each case the comparisons with experimental findings showed good correlation with the numerical predictions.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: It is well known that the problem of the environmental impact of energy conversion systems is particularly significant in the automotive field as a consequence of the widespread use of internal-combustion engines within transportation systems and because of the very high concentration of vehicles in urban areas.

Besides the impact on the air quality, vehicles are also responsible for increasing levels of noise emissions. A study carried out by the World Health Organization demonstrated that 45% of the urban population are subjected to a daytime (from 6 am to 10 pm) equivalent noise level of about 70–75 dBA, while during the night this decreases slightly to 65–70 dBA. The same study also recognized that transportation systems were the main sources of noise pollution.

The acoustic performance of a vehicle, therefore, plays a key aspect in the phase of the engine design, at a level increasingly focused on its power output, fuel consumption and pollutants emission. Some components, traditionally conceived just to optimize the energy conversion process, are today being designed by also keeping in mind the level of noise that they generate. This is the case, for example, for the intake system, from the intake mouth up to the valves.1

The overall noise level radiated by a vehicle is made up of contributions from many noise sources (engine, intake, exhaust, tyres, etc.). The relative contributions of the various noise sources can be measured, during a homologation test, using different procedures for source ranking. Usually the intake system is responsible for 25–50% of the overall radiated noise.2

The engine power output is closely related to the design of the intake system, which affects the volumetric efficiency of the single cylinder, namely the ratio of the air mass flow rate for a working cycle to the air mass flow rate theoretically entering the cylinder under ambient temperature and pressure. The volumetric efficiency is in fact strongly influenced by the pressure losses due to the air viscosity, and hence by the characteristics of the filter box and the shape and dimensions of the intake ducts. The fact that the alternate openings and closings of the cylinder intake valves determine pressure oscillations within the ducts should also be considered. These oscillations propagate along the intake system at the speed of sound, are partially reflected at each discontinuity and interact each with each other. The pressure waves, if well exploited, constitute a beneficial effect in filling the cylinders.3,4 However, they also constitute the source of a gas-dynamic noise since, when they reach the inlet section of the intake system, they also radiate noise to the environment.5,6

During wave propagation in the ducts, part of the energy is even transmitted to the structure, which, consequently, radiates noise to the atmosphere. The mean air flow also generates an aerodynamic noise at high frequencies, owing to the separation of vortices corresponding to obstacles encountered in its path; this is commonly known as ‘auto-generated noise’. The latter overlaps the noise derived from the pressure oscillations, is predominant starting from frequencies of some kilohertz and significantly increases with increasing engine speed. Similar considerations can be made with reference to the exhaust system.7–9

The reduction in the noise originating from the intake system is generally effected by introducing one or more resonators into the air filter box, which are able to attenuate the amplitude of pressure oscillations before they reach the section that is in contact with the atmosphere. Constructive constraints imposed from the layout of the engine space must also be fulfilled.
The main air-box requirements are hence the following.

list-item.p: Acoustic functionality. The necessary attenuations of the sound pressure must be assured in the low-frequency range because of their high levels, and in the upper-to-middle-frequency range because of the particular sensitivity of the human ear.

Fluid-dynamic functionality. The chosen configurations must realize the maximum volumetric efficiency and low pressure losses in the mean flow field in such a way that the engine can produce the maximum power output.
Mechanical functionality. The design, in terms of the layout and materials, must assure sufficient reliability and resistance to the mechanical stresses and to corrosion.
Inertia and stiffness.The inertia and stiffness characteristics of these components, as for the whole intake system, must also minimize noise transmission through the walls and the supports.

sec.p: The objective of the present work is to develop integrated numerical and experimental methodologies for prediction and enhancement of the acoustic performance of an air filter box of an internal-combustion engine for automotive applications.

Several contributions can be found in the current literature on the design and analysis of such a component. The most common approach is to employ one-dimensional (1D) models (only applicable in the plane wave regime) to characterize the ‘transmission loss’ (TL) of the isolated component10 and the gas-dynamic noise radiated when it is coupled to the engine.4,5 Since the plane wave regime is established only at low frequencies, a multi-dimensional approach is needed for accurate predictions at higher frequencies.11,12 Alternative methods can be applied too, such as the finite element method (FEM) or the boundary element method (BEM), which solve the Helmholtz equation in its three-dimensional (3D) form.13 They also allow fluid–structure interactions to be taken into account and noise contributions from component vibrations to be computed.

In the present paper, all the above methodologies are applied and integrated in order to exploit the advantages fully and to overcome the drawbacks of the individual methods. The approach to the problem that will be followed consists of a preliminary analysis of the individual component, and its successive coupling to the engine under real working conditions.

The air filter box of a four-cylinder, naturally aspirated spark ignition engine is considered for the present study, as sketched in Figure 1. In its original configuration, the air filter box consists of five elements: an inflow pipe (1), a pre-filter chamber (2), a section lodging the filtering element (3), a post-filter chamber (4) including two internal plates playing the role of resonators, and a short outflow pipe (5).

caption.p: Sketch of the considered air filter box.

sec.p: The paper is organized as follows. In the second section, the investigation on the internal gas dynamics of the air induction system is reported. Grids of different resolution are utilized to characterize the steady 3D flow inside the device and to predict the realized pressure losses.
The third section is devoted to a brief description of the experimental apparatus involved in the determination of the typical acoustic performance parameters: the noise reduction (NR) and the TL.

The results of the 3D fluid-dynamic analysis are post-processed to estimate the NR parameter in the fourth section. The effect of some geometrical modifications in the base design of the filter-box device, having the role of resonators, is also investigated in the same section.

Both the base and the modified component are also analysed in the fifth section by means of a 3D BEM, which is well known to require high computational and memory resources. These analyses aim to predict the TL parameter, which more precisely characterizes the acoustic attenuation of the air box.

The filter–engine coupling is then effected in the sixth section, by using a 1D numerical code, where the engine layout is reproduced through a series of ducts, in which elements such as the cylinder are considered as zero dimensional. The 1D code solves the Euler equations for compressible fluid dynamics, whose source terms include the contributions derived from the section variations along the ducts, the friction phenomena at the wall and the thermal exchange. The limits and inadequacies of a 1D air-box schematization are overcome by integrating 1D and 3D analyses, through definition of proper boundary conditions.

Finally, an additional FEM–BEM procedure is developed in the same section, starting from initial conditions provided by the 1D code and finalized, in single-engine operating conditions (3000 r/min), also to estimate the effects of the structure characteristics on the radiated gas-dynamic noise.

In each section, the comparison with the related experimental data makes it possibile to verify and validate the various numerical approaches. The conclusion section summarizes the main results and closes the paper.

sec.title: 3D modelling of the internal flow
sec.p: The 3D modelling of the air flow field within the filter box is based on numerical solution of the Reynolds-averaged Navier–Stokes equations,14 including a k–ε model for turbulence.15 A coarser grid and a finer grid are constructed, the relevant data for which are displayed in Table 1. The finer grid is constructed, paying attention to both the internal geometric details and the external geometric details. For this reason it is unstructured and of a multi-block type. The coarse grid is structured but presents some geometric simplifications.

caption.p: Relevant data on constructed unstructured and structured grids.

sec.p: In order to test the grid invariance of the results, a first stationary case is considered, having as boundary conditions an entering mass flow equal to 0.046 kg/s at a temperature of 293 K and a static pressure of 1.01 × 105 Pa, applied at the filter-box exit section. The chosen mass flow rate represents the average value of this quantity, as evaluated for the whole range of engine operating conditions.

Figure 2, as an example, represents the velocity field obtained on the finer grid, on a plane inclined at 11° with respect to the horizontal position. A plane orthogonal to the inlet section is considered as horizontal in the chosen reference frame. Recirculation zones are clearly detectable in the bottom right zone of the device. The latter, indeed, are not well described in the coarse grid. For this reason the reported results refer to only the finer mesh. No appreciable variations occur in the temperature field; hence the flow can be considered as isothermal.

sec.title: Experimental evaluation of the noise attenuation characteristics
sec.p: A simple experimental apparatus is installed in an acoustically insulated room in order to measure the attenuation curve of the tested system.9,10 A sketch of the experimental set-up is reported in Figure 4. The test facility consists of sound source equipment and sound measurement equipment. Source sound is produced through a random-noise generator, an amplifier and a loudspeaker unit, exciting a sound field with a dominating plane wave mode. The measurement apparatus consists indeed of a sound intensity probe (B&K model), a fast Fourier transform (FFT) analyser (LMS Scadas III system), an anechoic box and dedicated software for the NR and TL calculations. The acoustic excitation provided by a loudspeaker is insulated in a sound-proof box radiating a random signal (generated by the analyser) which is fed into the upstream section of the component. A sound intensity probe is used to recover the contribution from the downstream section. At the same time, the upstream loudspeaker signal pu(t) and the downstream measured sound intensity pd(t) are acquired and processed.

sec.title: Modified system analysis: effects of the resonators
sec.p: The above-described numerical approach is here extended to study different filter-box geometries, which are suitable for improving the noise attenuation characteristics of the considered component. Two different resonators, namely a Helmholtz resonator and a column resonator, are added to the intake duct geometry in order to increase the attenuation in both the low-frequency range and the high-frequency range. The geometrical characteristics of the Helmholtz resonator are appropriately designed in order to obtain resonance in the low-frequency range (below 400 Hz), while the column resonator is dimensioned in such a way as to improve the high-frequency response (above 700 Hz). Table 2 summarizes the design data and the expected resonance frequencies of the two resonators.

Figure 10 displays a comparison between the computed NR values for the base and the computed NR values for the modified system. The introduction of the Helmholtz resonator not only produces a considerable NR increase (more than 20 dB) at about 330 Hz but also improves the value of this parameter over a wide range of frequencies (270–420 Hz). A slight penalty, instead, is paid at about 240 Hz.

sec.title: Base system analysis
sec.p: An alternative methodology for numerical evaluation of the TL is based on a 3D BEM acoustic analysis.6,18 In this study, the commercial software VNOISE® is used. The 3D BEM analysis of the system is a powerful tool for more accurate performance prediction and system design. The latter, however, requires high computational and memory resources. Only a surface mesh is required in this case, which is constructed by means of the commercial software FEMAP 9.0®.

Figure 11 reports the meshed model of the modified system with the previously designed resonators. It consists of 16,444 nodes and 16,442 shell elements. Internal geometrical details, such as the presence of the extended tube placed within the expansion chamber, are detectable in Figure 11. The frequency range of interest is limited by the chosen mesh size (six elements per wavelength). Also, this cut-off frequency is much higher than the maximum working frequency of the tested system (in fact, the harmonic components of the engine excitation lies well below 1000 Hz).

sec.title: Modified system analysis: resonators and structural participation effects
sec.p: In order to enhance and verify the results presented above, a new 3D BEM analysis was realized, taking into account the effects exerted by the structural participation. The first step in this case is the FEM calculation of natural vibration modes of the devices. As an example, Figure 13(a) and (b) shows the natural modes of the lower air-box surface occurring at 680 Hz and the natural modes of the upper air-box surface occurring at 970 Hz respectively. The latter were found to affect the TL profile considerably, as shown in Figure 14. Structural modes are also responsible for some signal amplifications at particular frequencies (630 Hz, 730 Hz and 1080 Hz).

sec.title: Experimental analysis and characteristic data of the tested engine
sec.p: In order to analyse the behaviour of the considered air filter box under real engine operating conditions, both the base and the modified system are considered as coupled to a medium-size spark ignition engine. The engine, whose main characteristics are reported in Table 3, is installed on a test bench to determine its performances experimentally in terms of the air flow, the torque and the power. The same engine, coupled to the two systems, is also installed on a real vehicle to measure the gas-dynamic noise at a distance of 5 cm from the intake mouth.

sec.title: The 1D–3D model
sec.p: The computational code employed in the 1D simulation was developed at the Dipartimento di Meccanica ed Energetica, Università Degli Studi di Napoli Federico II.19 It can handle all main engine configurations, because of the very versatile and modular structure. In fact, it has been successfully applied during the last few years to the analysis of naturally aspirated engines20,21 and turbocharged engines.22 The quoted papers emphasize the potential of the code in modelling the combustion phenomenon and in capturing the basic effects related to variation in the intake and exhaust valve events. They also reported an extensive description of the model characteristics.
The numerical procedure includes a reliable 1D flow model for the computation of wave propagation phenomena in the manifolds, described by the equation
where

The terms ρ, u, p, E = cvT+u2/2 and H = cpT+u2/2 in the system of equations (14) represent the air density, the velocity, the pressure, the total energy and the enthalpy per unit mass respectively. The source term S accounts for the duct area variation α, the friction term f and the rate q of heat exchange. The last two equations in system (14) allow the correct estimation of the gas composition inside each cylinder, which is especially important under conditions of intake or exhaust backflows (internal exhaust gas recirculation). The fuel burning rate is computed using a two-zone turbulent combustion model, based on a fractal description of the flame front area. The model accounts for the effects of the turbulence intensity, the air-to-fuel ratio, the spark advance, the load conditions and the residual mass fraction. The in-cylinder turbulence levels are estimated with a modified K–k approach.21

As concerns the computation of the gas-dynamic noise, the model employs a classical formulation for reconstruction of the acoustic pressure field p(r, t) at a distance r from the intake mouth and at time t, as a function of the ambient density ρ, the speed c of sound and the derivative of the velocity signal u(t) at the intake mouth,19 which is given by
The above equation, which holds for hemispherical wave propagation, finally allows estimation of the SPL through the relation

For better accuracy, a spline reconstruction of the velocity signal is performed and its derivative is then analytically computed. An FFT analysis of the pressure profile can also be carried out in order to derive the pressure spectrum in the frequency domain and to identify the main engine orders. (An order k is defined as a multiple frequency above the base frequency (360° rotational frequency). For a four-cylinder four-stroke engine, two cylinders typically fire during each revolution, so that the most interesting orders are the second, the fourth and the sixth orders.) Equation (15) really holds at a distance r sufficiently large with respect to the equivalent radius of the intake mouth. This condition is only partly verified in the present case, and this may affect the numerical results.

The whole considered engine is schematized as a network of pipes and cylinders. The 1D schematization of the air filter box is in particular shown in Figure 16(a). It takes into account the presence of the two internal resonators (pipes R1 and R2), the column resonator (indicted by C) and the Helmholtz resonator (indicated by H) along the inflow pipe.

1D: one-dimensional; 3D: three-dimensional; R1, R2: internal resonators (pipes); C: column resonator; H: Helmholtz resonator.

sec.p: A more recent feature of the 1D code is the possibility of carrying out a fully integrated 1D–3D analysis, by means of a time-based coupling with a 3D CFD code. An original coupling procedure is developed between the 1D and 3D codes, based on the exchange of the instantaneous static and total pressures at the interface sections between the two models. The 3D grid is considered by the 1D model as a ‘virtual pipe’ whose end sections are loaded with the average static and total pressures derived by the 3D resolution. Then a classic pipe-to-pipe junction is solved by the 1D side to update the thermo-fluid-dynamic data in the adjacent (real) pipes. The latter data are used in the next time step as a boundary condition for the 3D computation.

Therefore, a 1D–3D schematization of the considered system is realized, too, as shown in Figure 16(b). Both the base and the modified air filter box are simulated and compared. In order to limit the computational time, however, the 1D–3D results refer to only the coarse grids.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The ‘stand-alone’ 1D model and the coupled 1D–3D procedure were employed to characterize the performance parameters of the tested engine. With the aim of better describing the actual flow losses, data derived from the preliminary steady flow 3D analysis (Figure 3) are utilized in the stand-alone 1D model to tune the friction coefficient correlations in the pipes constituting the air box.

Figure 17(a) shows the air flow and volumetric efficiency profiles computed by the two approaches in the full engine speed range, under wide-open throttle conditions. It must be pointed out that simulation of each of the 10 operating point requires computation of 10 consecutive engine cycles to obtain a converged periodic solution. For this reason, 100 unsteady CFD analyses of the flow inside the air box were computed in the 1D–3D approach.

caption.p: (a) Air flow and volumetric efficiency; (b) shaft power and torque.
1D: one-dimensional; 3D: three-dimensional; rpm: r/min.
Source: reprinted with permission from SAE paper 2007-01-0380 © 2007 SAE International.11

sec.p: The results in Figure 17 demonstrate that introduction of the two resonators does not substantially alter the engine filling conditions and power output. Moreover, agreement with the experimental data seems reasonable, and both the 1D model and the 1D–3D model are able to reproduce the two peaks of volumetric efficiency at 3000 r/min and 4500 r/min. The coupled 1D–3D procedure, although much more time consuming, does not seem to improve the results considerably. Probably, engine filling conditions are only slightly affected by the unsteady flow inside the air box, and, in addition, the 1D analysis takes advantage of the included steady flow results.

Similar considerations can be obtained by looking at the power and torque profiles in Figure 17(b). The satisfactory agreement which is displayed demonstrates that the fractal combustion model, briefly summarized in the section on the 1D model, is able to reproduce the rate of heat release at each engine speed.22 Some minor inaccuracies can be accepted because a unique set of the tuning constants of the combustion model is specified. A more direct comparison with the experimental profiles of the in-cylinder pressure cycle is considered to be beyond the scope of the present work.

sec.title: Radiated noise 1D and 1D–3D results
sec.p: Additional experimental data were collected on the tested engine coupled to the base and modified air-box devices and installed inside a vehicle. Overall SPL data are measured during a fast vehicle acceleration manoeuvre in third gear. Figure 18 reports the numerical and experimental comparisons of the A-weighted SPL traces (dB(A)) for the base and modified system, as well. The presence of the two resonators slightly improves the overall noise at high engine speeds, as expected. The data agreement, particularly for the 1D–3D approach, is accurate over the total engine speed range, except for the 4500 r/min and 5000 r/min cases. The coupled 1D–3D procedure allows improvement in the results in the low-speed and medium-speed ranges. Computations are able to reproduce the slight improvement at high engine speeds determined by the presence of the resonators. More detailed comparisons are displayed in Figures 19 and 20, referring to the base and modified systems respectively. These show the evolution behaviours of the main engine orders (second, fourth and sixth) versus the engine speed. Following the engine order definition (f = kn/60), data are also plotted versus the frequency.

sec.p: Both procedures accurately describe the second-order profiles, representing the main harmonic of the radiated SPL, in the low-frequency range. The agreement is indeed less satisfactory for the fourth order. A relevant SPL underestimation is in fact found at 4500 r/min and 5000 r/min for the modified system. The above operating conditions lie very close to the resonance frequency of the Helmholtz resonator (300–350 Hz). The computed results, hence, seem to be much more sensitive to the effect of this resonator with respect to the experimental data. The agreement for the sixth order is still satisfactory, and the 1D–3D approach gives here the most significant improvement.

As a further consideration, it must be pointed out that the high-frequency attenuation exerted by the column resonator produces a reduced contribution in terms of the overall SPL expressed in linear dB. A more pronounced influence is indeed found on the overall SPL in dB(A), owing to the A-weighting filtering of the low-frequency contributions. This also explains why the high NR and TL improvements realized by the Helmholtz resonator (see Figures 10 and 12) have only a minor impact on the gas-dynamic noise. The improvement in the overall SPL is therefore mainly related to the presence of the column resonator.
More pronounced benefits could be obtained directly acting on the volume of the air filter box. The latter is, however, limited by constraints exerted by the engine bay inside the vehicle.

sec.title: Radiated noise FEM–BEM results
sec.p: An additional FEM–BEM approach was performed to include the structural participation effects in the predicted gas-dynamic noise levels.23

The calculation of the radiated noise from the modified filter box is effected by imposing at the section connected to the engine a time-varying pressure signal provided by the above-described 1D model at 3000 r/min. According to the experimental arrangement, the presence of a microphone at a distance of 5 cm from the intake mouth was been considered. The same boundary conditions are also employed to evaluate the radiated noise at a distance of 1 m from the radiating source, over a spherical surface surrounding the air-box device (ISO 3746). Both the analyses are realized neglecting or considering the fluid–structure interaction, with the scope of quantifying the incidence of the elasticity of the structure over the radiated gas-dynamic noise.

Figure 21 shows the pressure distributions over a sphere at distance of 1 m at the typical frequency of 100 Hz, without and with structural participation. The comparison between the above figures clearly provides evidence that the structure, with its elasticity, affects the noise distribution over the entire measurement surface, as well as on the structure itself. The absence of elasticity of the structure justifies the high-pressure distribution occurring in the zone directly facing the air inlet section (Figure 21(a)). A lower noise level is achieved in the case of structural participation (Figure 21(b)). This indicates that the elasticity of the structure at this particular frequency reduces the overall sound level, because of the energy absorbed by the structure itself.

Finally, the overall noise level (dB(A)) at a distance of 5 cm from the intake mouth is plotted in Figure 22 in the one-third octave frequency band, for the two considered cases. The figure highlights relevant variations in the pressure spectra for the two cases, thereby confirming the importance of considering the elasticity of the structure in the numerical analyses. The global outcome is an overall SPL level of about 110 dB(A) with structure participation. This fully complies with the experimentally evaluated value at the rotational speed of 3000 r/min, as shown in Figure 18(b).

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, the whole design and development procedure of an air filter box for a spark ignition engine is followed, starting from a base device and employing experimental measurements and theoretical models.

Different numerical techniques, namely 3D CFD, the 1D method, the FEM and the BEM, are to a great extent integrated and utilized to predict and enhance the acoustic performance of the device. The results presented show that the FEM–BEM approach better characterizes the acoustic behaviour of the isolated component in a wide frequency range and can account for structural participation effects. The 1D and 3D fluid-dynamic approaches also allow the pressure losses and gas-dynamic noise of the entire engine system to be estimated. In particular, an integrated analysis method to be used in practical applications is proposed. It consists of the following steps.

list-item.p: First, a preliminary investigation of the internal gas dynamics of the air induction system is performed to characterize the steady 3D flow inside the air-box device and to estimate its discharge coefficient and pressure losses. A further unsteady 3D analysis is performed to predict the NR of the air-box device. The same parameter is also experimentally measured and compared with the numerical results. Reasonable agreement is found in a wide frequency range.

The effect of some geometrical modifications to the base air-box device, having the role of resonators, is then investigated. A noise attenuation improvement to the modified system is found in both the low-frquency range and the high-frequency range.

A coupled FEM–BEM numerical approach is used to describe the acoustic performance of the modified device better in terms of the TL, achieving very good agreement with the related experimental findings. The results presented demonstrated that non-negligible effects on the TL are determined by the elasticity of the structure.

1D analyses of the base and the acoustically improved system show that the presence of the two resonators does not substantially affect the volumetric efficiency of the whole engine. A more detailed 1D–3D procedure is set up and it is verified to realize better experimental correlation in the estimation of the gas-dynamic noise. In particular, the radiated noise results are accurate for the second order and are less precise for the higher orders, especially when the resonators are added. The 1D–3D technique is, however, able to predict contemporarily with satisfactory accuracy both the performance and the radiated noise of the tested intake system, in its whole speed range.

Finally, starting from the latter results, the gas-dynamic noise is computed again through a FEM–BEM technique by also taking into account the structural participation of the air filter box. Once again, good agreement with experimental data is obtained at an engine speed of 3000 r/min.

sec.p: The described methodology demonstrates how the exchange of information between very different numerical approaches may help the understanding of the system’s behaviour to improve its performance and to reduce the development time.
